text: Bottle at Portland tasting. 2012 harvest. Cidery white head, clearish yellow. Very funky nose. Sweet, funky yeast. Very rough fruit. Lots of vanilla. Nice.

750 ml bottle from The Party Source. Lovely shape and simple label, which states that the apples were harvested in 2015 and matured in calvados casks in 2016. Pours a mostly clear, but rich gold with a small fizzy white head that vanishes, although some tiny rising carbonation bubbles remain all the way down in my stemmed Oakhold glass. Notes of sweet apple, oak, vanilla, earth, caramel, and honey. The aroma is cleaner and more apple-forward and a little tart, while the flavor is sweeter and suggests more sugars. Medium-plus bodied, with low to modest carbonation and a sweet, coating, mostly smooth mouthfeel. Great stuff.

750 ml bottle. #4151. 7.5%. Vintage 2015. Courtesy of Euphemos.
Clear golden color with a tiny white head. 
Musty apple aroma with freshness, cork, cookie sweetness and some vanilla in the aroma. 
The flavor is dry apple, must, vanilla, sweetness, some cork and mild dessert wine notes. 
Soft carbonation. Almost too sweet.

Pours yellow-gold and clear with a small white head. Aroma is fermented apples and a medicinal botrytis-like funk. Taste is sweet with mellow apple flavors leading to a medicinal fungal finish. Not bad.

75cl bottle. Pours clear deep gold, thin white head that persists. Aroma of soft brown sugar, calvados, caramel. Taste is moderately sweet, fairly complex with some interesting vanilla, cinnamon and fudge notes rising above a medium apple fruit character. Relatively subtle calvados influence which I think benefits the cider well. Very good.

Bottle: Vintage 2013: Served in a Chouffe glass:
Lively and quick disappearing white head. Cloudy yellow body.
Nose of apple skin, ferme ted apple, cellar, stone, wood, spice, earth, cabbage, rubber...
Flavour of apples, liquor, bitter tart (not sour), vinous, wood, earth, grapes, apple peel/skin, fermented apples, light dust and sulphur...
Aftertaste is earthy, sulphur, apple peel, tart (not sour), little chemical...
Medium carbo, sparkling mouthfeel, more than medium bodied.
Does not get better with time and air. Every sip gets more difficult... pfff...

text: Bottle, courtesy of SinH4, 2015 vintage. Pours clear golden. Aroma is light funk, but also clearly a lot of dry green apples. Body is medium and fruity sweet, crisp carbonation. Palate lingers with sweet apples, lots of flesh. Juicy and really tasty, but just a tad too sweet for the ultimate drinking experience. I should age this.

Bottle shared with a friend, poured a deep yellow golden colour, nose of fresh sweet apple juice, vanilla, green apples, light sweet pears, oak, warm sweetness of calvados barrels, light cinnamon, brightly carbonated. Refreshing

pours almost clear bright yellow with a small white cap, healthy bubbles. woodsy honeyed apples, soft tannins - obvious calvados; leaves, lots of flowers, yeast, minerals. bright carbonation, light to medium body - oily; semi-sweet and woody lightly tannic finish. semi-sweet oaky cider with lots of farmhouse character, which is domaine familial duponts signature. much enjoyed!

Clear golden color, a bit of off-white head. Aroma has intense fermented apples and some oak. Taste is really sweet at first with ripe apples, honey and some apple pits bitterness on the finish. Overall its quite sweet, not really easy to drink but quite tasty.

Golden color with hardly any head. Aroma is sweet natural apples, wood, caramel, some funk. Taste is sweet apples, also tartness, wood, some tannins, some calvados hotness im the back, but very balanced. Effervescent carbonation. Sweet, but in a natural way, and awesomely so. Still, its quite sweet, not for everybody.

(bottle) clear golden colour with a quickly-diminishing white head. aroma of mealy apples and melted butter, with a touch of vanilla, some white wine vinegar and white bread rolls. flavour is mostly the same, heavy apples and vanilla, very sweet, with some notes of tobacco and brown sugar in the finish. heavy-bodied with lively carbonation. too sweet.

Bautiful gold without real head. Aroma is natural apple, sweet and sour. Taste is sweet and sour, comparable with honey, very nice. Medium carbonated, very apple juicy finish. This tastes like a very good mix of apple juice and water. A little dryness later. This is good.
Young Bottle. Golden. Great light fermented apple aroma, sparkly light sweet, dry, start of a white wine note, sweet finish. Room for things to happen.

Shared bottle. Pours is clear golden. Aroma is vinous, fresh apples, apple zest, calvados, light basement aromas. Taste is light sweet, fresh apples, light calvados on tongue. Heavy body, slick texture, soft carbonation, light alcohol warmth in finish. Awesome.

Robe dorée de fines bulles viennent perler en surface.
 Le nez souvre sur des arômes de comptée, de bois et de calva.
La bouche est douce et délicate, les notes de calva sont plus marquées.
La finale est légèrement sèche et élégante.

Bottle shared thanks to Clownoisseur for the trade. Clear golden with with a few bubbles. Lots of sweet apples, dry cellar funk, wood, dusty apple skins, light booze, dried apple. Under medium sweet with dusty and mineral bitter finish. Medium bodied with a bit of fizzy carbonation and a bit dry feel. Good stuff.
Yellow color. Aromas of apples, calvados, slight acidic. Apple tasting, slight acidic, calvados, wood. Very well balanced, redefining cider as a concept for me.

From bottle at Vill & Syrlig Festival 2015. Unclear golden body with a small white head. Aroma of wood, green apples, vanilla, horseblanket. Taste is dry, full loaded of juicy apples, mild funky. Finish of leather and apples. Quite good.
From the shared bottle. Apple brandy funky nose clear yellow goodness. Changed my mind about cidre. Really good.

Pours really clear golden with nice bubble streams. Nose is of barnyard, light horse and oak. Taste is where calvados is more apparent: moderately sweet apples with some spirits and good oak. Light funk. Body is moderate, carbonation too. Quite tannic with some drying qualities. A pretty good farmhouse cider that I wish would showcase more of the calvados.
Bottle at Salon piva. Golden hazy color. Aroma of apples, pineapples and tropical fruits, oak, hints of spirit. Taste is complexed, balanced, tuned, sweet, light sour. Nice

Heller apfeliger, sehr würziger Cider. Feine Karbonisierung, holzig, die Apfelnoten sind fein und dunkel. Spritzig, süß karamellig, geringe Herbe. Steigend holzig, Nuancen von Vanille und Johannisbeere. Lang und weich ausgleitend. 9/13/12/13/11/13

Holy crap what a cider. Bottle from 2012. Cork shot into the ceiling. bright golden straw colour with heavy streams of carbonation and a spritz of bubbles on the surface. The nose is woody, a tad smoky with tons of toffee, caramel and vanilla. Rich apple and caramel notes with brown sugar and a heavy woody profile. Touch of sweetness throughout with a lingering wood flavour. Holy crap is that good.

(75 cl. Lot: 41132. 7.5%) La robe or scintille et les bulles qui montent à la surface finissent par mhypnotiser. Le nez souvre sur des parfums de cidre campagnard et de vin blanc. Il est également marqué par des notes boisés et des notes de fruits jaunes. La bouche est élégante mais pas transcendante avec des notes de calvados bien placées dans cette structure fermière élaborée par les pommes et leurs levures indigènes. En bouche, le pétillement naturel flatte chacune de mes papilles. La finale sèche nest pas intense mais bien raffinée. Il y a un art derrière ce cidre vieilli.

Bottle. Thanks!

N: Caramel, apple, some toffee, brown sugar, and brandy.

T: Sweet and tart. Big on the sweet.

M: Light body, no alcohol, crisp carbonation.

O: A fine way to cap off the night. I enjoyed it as a change of pace, and I assume I would enjoy it just as much were it on its own.

Bottle at home, shared with the misses. Pours intense golden yellow. Fine carbonation. Nice evolved apple aroma, even with strong sweet white wine flavours. This cide really is a refined piece of art. Thick sweet mouthfeel, nice fruit sour in the bridge. This is a real threat, thanks to Ronald for this kind and truly special gift!

Bottle (750 ml) at home. 2013 bottle. Thanks to KCherney for this one! Split 4-ways. Almost clear bright golden with a small bubbly ring of white foam. Aroma was a bit dull at first with only some generic apple fruitiness but after 15+ minutes it opened up a lot letting the farmy horsey character out along Calvados spiciness and tingling alcohol. Taste is bright from the start with gentle tartness, a bit of residual sugar but nothing too much, lots of horsey character, the calvados spiciness is much more present here but not the boozy aspect. Body is medium. Carbonation is moderate. Mouthfeel is a bit tannic. Finish is dry, but much less than the Bordatto ciders we had just before. A very interesting product. I was quite disappointed by the aroma at first, but the taste was great and ultimately the aroma became much better once it opened up. Really good.

Delar en flaska med Isabel en torsdag. Från ett släpp på sb nyligen.
Jäklar! Här har vi en delikat cider. Doften är stiltypiskt fransk med övermogna äpplen som dominerar. Men här finns så mycket mer jag sällan upplevt i en cider tidigare, även från franska premiumgrejer. Kunde inte pricka in att den legat på calvadosfat, men nu när man vet om det var det lättare att känna. Perfekt ton med subtil calvados lyfter ytterligare en nivå. Jag är imponerad. I tried this probably at my first ratebeer tasting, which was hosted by Paul. Drove from Staten Island to Jersey before Paul got upscale and moved on up to the Hoboken side. Or maybe it was a different Paul tasting. A Jersey RBian, who did not stay active long, shared this cider. At that time, it was pretty damn cool. Back then an upper teens cost of something was big money. I think we all appreciated the expenditure. Nowadays, its almost commonplace. I feel like this cider was much less available, definitely around but not overly common. I remember constantly seeing it at New Beer but never wanting to spend "that much" on a cider, even if it is barrel aged. Recently, I moved to Seattle and cider is big there, way bigger than anywhere else in the states. Maybe that is why I kept seeing this bottle for sale; much stronger visibility than I had been used to. I have been tempted to pick up a bottle especially given that the $20 price tag isnt really that large by contemporary standards. Fortunately, my uncle just brought this to a family gathering just for me. Hooray!.
I like Dupont cider, its the way I imagine cider should be done, effervescent, wild, not too apply, and not too sweet. However. these rules do not stand for ice ciders. This cider seems to be not wild, not effervescent but good, Why? because they make it a bit ice cider like with the calvados barrel. A bit of that heft from alcohol, sweet but worth sipping. Fun stuff but as an ice cider substitute as opposed to the regular Dupont lineup. See you again in 10 years cider.

750 ml bottle.
As the top-rated cider on the site, I was eager to a hold of this one, >$20 pricetag notwithstanding. I saved it for a winter Saturday afternoon of writing, where I could savor the flavors over the span of a few hours. It opens with an ample puff and smokes for a moment. Poured into the long-stemmed tulip that I like for ciders, it immediately presents a vigorous churning white head that then disappears in seconds, leaving a rich gold liquid with the occasional trail of rising bubbles. 
 The aroma is complex. The oak from the calvados is present; of course apple but this element is actually relatively subdued; some unwelcome sulfuric notes; rotten wood, a touch of rubbing alcohol, the proverbial horseblanket. The flavor provides an interesting combination of gentle apple sweetness in the mid-sip with a dry tannic aspect later on. Wrapped around all of this are multiple layers of apple flavor: simple and light juice, musty cider, rich and somewhat sharp calvados. The combination is intriguing and far from straightforward. Mouthfeel is full without pushing over into sticky; mouth-filling carbonation is not too sharp; a bit more warmth on the back of the throat than one might expect at 6.9%. In the end I like this a lot, but Im not sure it has much on the better Washington ciders and it suffers all the more for its price point. A good reference but not a regular drinker. 

tl;dr summary: Complex BA cider bests its French competition.

Bottle courtesy of Saxo. Clear golden without head. Aroma is sweet, apples, light sulphur, wood and light barnyard. Flavor is quite sweet and light acidic. Dry and light acidic finish. 311212

On tap at Proletariat prior to heading to Andys for New Years.  Pours a hazed gold.  Soft musk on the nose, funky wood, tart yeast, loads of phenolic notes.  Sweet apples, funky and yeast, with a bit of a sweet-tart flavor.  Almost acidic and sour, wood and funk.  Tart and sweet, long earthy yeast.

From bottle at tuulensuu. Hazy golden color, small white head staying. Sour aroma of apples, citrus, sweetness and some stables. Taste mixing fresh apples, sour, stables. Nice and refreshing.

On tap at Taste of Belgium. $8 for the flute. Pours a mildly hazy light yellow color. White head quickly fades to nothing. Bubbly in the body. Pleasant nose of apple, with some wood-must and spice. Flavor doesnt stand too much out from the typical high-end cider, but the finish is where this stands out. Nice subtle note of wood (presumably calvados) that works well with the cider. Hint of pineapple juice. Medium / bigger body. Light carbonation. Light sweet / tart taste, but also a good bit of bitter balance. Very nice comlexity, good dry finish, but the calvados is very subtle. Good cider, but still not something significantly more exciting than the typical premium cider

Bottle. Golden colour with some white bubbles. Aroma is yeast, apple, alcohol. Flavour is apple, yeast, wood, alcohol. Full body. Very nice cider. Earlier Rating: 5/24/2007 Total Score: 3.8Bottle. Yellow/ golden colour . Aroma is sour, yeast, apple. Flavour is apple,yeast, sweet, sour. Nice cider.

Tap at Maxs Taphouse.  Pours clear light gold with a small, fizzy white head, short retention with no lacing.  Aroma is apple, band aid phenols, oak, and straw.  Flavor is heavy apple, light band aid and medicinal phenols, oak and a sweet finish.  Medium body and low to no carbonation.

Tap. Pours clear gold with thin fizzy white head that quickly dissipates. Aroma is apples, pears, cereal and cookie malt, floral notes, light grassy notes, and light banana. Flavor is heavy apple and sweet malts with the same floral and grassy notes found in the nose; lightly sweet finish that smoothly dries out. Light body and medium carbonation.

Draft, thanks Travlr.  Still apple juice body.  Aroma is moderately sweet, apple, apple brandy, some tartness.  Taste is moderately sweet, apple brandy, some apple, honey, light duskiness.  Smooth medium body.

Draft at Churchkey. Clear honey colored pour with minimal bubbly head. Nose and flavor bring gorgeous tart apple skins, hints of oak tannin, funk, cheesecloth, and apple juice. Flavor brings a touch less acidity and bite, but still that amazing complex real apple skin character. Clean, refreshing, and ridiculously clean for 7%; I cant even imagine the volume I could drink were it cheaper. Fantastic.

Draft at ChurchKey. Hazy golden yellow color, fizzy white edge head that lasts forever. Aroma of dusty and funky dried apple skins and honey. Taste is fizzy barnyard apples and dusty lemon skins. Delicious.

75 cl bottle. Pale yellow color, very small and quickly disappearing white head. Woody apple aroma, calvados, pear, orange, leather notes, funky, earthy, honey notes but still dry. Apple and honey flavor, woody, calvados, vanilla, mango, dry, earthy, pear, leather, some alcohol notes, raisins, horse blanket, decent carbonation. Woody funky finish with apples, grapes, leather and honey. By far the best cider I have tried.

2010(?) bottle from Jimmy 43s. Split among a few friends while winding down from Applepalooza 12.

Short wine glass. A splash of fizz. Slightly unsettled, pale wheat body. Lighting was moody, so I could be off.

Slightly funky/musky nose. Tart, bittersweet apple skin. Mushroom stuffiness.

Tastes of earthy, creamy/browned dessert apples, with some painless warming brandy/honey on the trail.

A little twinge of acidity accentuated by the tight carbonation. Flinty finish.

Compact & savory, while still managing to be quite refreshing. Awesome.

Pours golden, no head.  Smells fruity.  Tastes like slightly carameled apple.  Sweety apple, wine, candy.  Finishes clean.

On tap at northdown. Never seen this on tap before so nice. Real nice... Bottle. Clear golden colour with a quickly fading medium sized white head. Strong apple aroma. Flavour is sweet apple, oak.

Sample at a tasting. Interesting smell, farm yard and fruits. Sweet taste with apple-fruits, pears to be exact. Unfortunately the farm aromas doesnt show up in the taste. Semi-dry cider that doesnt stifling. Fresh.

2010 Apples Matured in 2011 ... Clear golden pour well carbonated and a nice fizzy appearance with a thin white head ....  aroma is of crisp fresh apples, lightly musty and of oak ...... taste is of crisp apples, light oak light warming abv, apple peels and a dry lightly bitter bite that lingers into the finish .... the mouthfeel is dry, fizzy/lively and crisp .... awesome cider

They should have called this one the fuggin cold cut cider...but anyways...The pour is an effervescent clear yellow with a big bubbly, almost fake co2, head that died like a soda pops carbonation. The nose is dried apples, some light bourbon notes, and a smokey quality. This one is just right with sweetness - not too dry, not too sweet. The taste is pretty darn similar to how it smells but more intense in flavor. Apples, brandy, some sweetness, light smoke. Not bad at all. Head starts of fizzy but fades to meek coverage good carbonation gold pour aromas apple vinegar some funky earthy notes woodyness sweet fruit tart strong cheese white wine the flavours pear apple that strong calvados influence earthyness musky taste vinegar light acidity smooth has a sparkling wine touch to it the finish a lovely sweetness tart fruit acidity calvados influence superb woodness lashings of flavours in the aftertaste a superb cider

2011 bottle, cork says D 1024 - Pours pale yellow with a ring of white head. Cascading bubbles from the bottom of the glass. Nose is funky earth, cheese, white grape, tart apple. 750 ml bottle. Pours light yellow, with a full head quickly dissolving. Very bubbly, but still a feeling of moderate carbonation when tasting. Aroma is very fruity, with almost brett-like notes, as well as grapes, earth, barrel and white wine. Flavour is sweet of apples and some tropical notes of mango, pineapple and flowers, as well as grapes and a vinous oakiness.

Yellow in colour with no head, light alcohol lacing.  A little cider vinegar in the aroma, oak, wood, earth, good sweetness, apples.  The flavour is sweet, lots of apples, oak, green apples, caramel.  Smooth mouthfeel, medium/light body, mild carbonation.  Finishes long, sweet, apple skins.

Aged amazing.  Smells like a gueuze and drinks like a still cider.  Unreal.

Body has good levels of carbonation with some weight to it, but could be a little crisper. Overall, this is a well executed cider. I love the nose, but the flavor is just a tad sweeter than I would like. Still pretty tasty and worth picking up a bottle or two.

750 ml bottle. Clear golden body with lively carbonation and a medium white head that fades. Aroma is cider apples, ripe apples, fruit and wood. Aroma is strong sulfates up front, wood, near-salty tones and merely hints of apples. Strange. Taste is light acidic tones, wood, apple cores and hints of herbs. Balanced, and with a soft carbonation with carries the semi-dryness of this cider well. Pretty drinkable, but I lack the apple-ness both in nose and mouth. A nice cider. Sure. Number 1? Not in my book.
Sediment present. slight golden colour. apple aroma with a oak barrel aroma. has an almost vodka like note to me. big flavours, long finish, balanced brew. overall great experience.

Im no cider expert but I would imagine this is almost as good as it gets.

0.75l corked bottle. A fantastic looking bottle this and already before popping the cork, Im almost in love with this cider just based on the looks of the bottle... In short: A pleasant cider with an old wood barrel and farmhouse character.  Nice.
How: Bottle 750ml, corked & caged.  Apples harvested in 2008, bottled in 2009  6.9% abv.  Consumed when between 1 and 2 year of age
The look:  Cloudy yellow blonde body topped by a tiny white ring of foam
In long: The abv was 6.9% and not 5.5% as currently listed on ratebeer, and I dont understand why there is currently a separate entry for the 2006 vintage because it is 7.5%, both entries should probably be merged.  NOW ON TO THE CIDER: The nose on this thing is honestly one of the most crazy thing I have ever smelled.  This is like walking in an old dank cellar with a lot of old moist barrels.  Fantastic nose really.  Taste is a bit of a letdown compared to the complexity of the nose.  concentrate apple juice, honeyed bread, brandy, tart green apples, a LOT of wood barrels, barnyard notes, some mead, moderately sweet, lots of small tickling bubbles and something a little cheesy in the yeastiness.  A little alcohol bite despite the low abv.  I liked this cider, but to be honest I am not very familiar with farmhouse ciders so I may be easily impressionable.  Everybody is ignorant, just on different subjects.

75 cl bottle. Almost clear, yellow/green grape liquid with small, fast dissipating white head. Aroma of apples, calvados, oak, vanilla and red apple skin. Taste is light to medium sweet, light tart and appley. Light to medium bodied with high carbonation. Overall, very well balanced and refreshing. Not too sweet, not too dry.

Some spices - cinnamon, vanilla - and alcohol at the end. Wood creeps in after a while. Seemed overcarbonated and too sweet at first, but pineapple and wood grew to check the sweetness although the lemon disappears completely. Good, complex cider that doesnt quite live up to its aroma.

text:
Appearance: Served up a brilliantly clear, deepened yellow body with a very thin head. A few streams of steady bubbles, like a miniature fish tank.

Smell: Tart, lightly sweet-scented nose of fresh, crisp cut apples backed by some light oak wood notes.

Taste: Quality gulp of apple juice, lightly sweet, but with a bright tartness. Clean, classy oak character with a small kiss of vanilla. Slight yeastiness. Biting rush of jolting CO2 on the dry, modestly puckering finish.

Mouthfeel: Medium-bodied. Arrives on the tongue seemingly very still, but then theres a blitz of lively carbonation, akin to pouring hydrogen peroxide on an oozing wound.

Drinkability: Its fun, tasty, and elegant. Its nice to get a cider that isnt just a mass-produced Woodchucker this or that.

750 ml bottle, 2006 harvest.  Clear gold with streaming bubbles that collect along the edge.  Nose is funky tart apple, pear and oak.  Silky smooth with tiny carb prickles.  Taste is baked apple, Granny Smith peels and mineral water.  Finishes dry and woody with a touch of apple jack.  Sophisticated, complex, crisp and clean.  Lovely.

UPDATED: MAY 5, 2011 Re-rate 5/1/11: Bottle sample at a tasting. Thanks zvikar. Recolte 2008. Clear golden color. Aroma of green apples and a bit of red ones, some wood and light funky hints. Sweetish-sourish glavor of apples and a bit of sugar. Nice and refreshing. 7/3/7/3/14=3.4

Bottle sample at a tasting. Thanks zvikar. Recolte 2007. 7.5% ABV. Clear golden. Aroma of green apples, oak, brett hints and a bit of alcohol. Sweetish-sourish flavor of fresh green apples, apple peels, some wood and earthy hints. Soft carbonation. Tasty and refreshing but a bit too sweet for my liking. 7/3/7/4/14=3.5

Bottle at a tasting: the aroma is very mush like a dry cider, some sourness, green apple, brett, hay, wet wood, vineger, the taste is pretty sweet and simple, green apple, red apple, wood again, honey like sweetness, pretty good cider.

Recolte 2007, at a tasting, many thanks Zvikar, almost no head and carbonation, a touch hazy lemon yellow colour,  aroma of  vinegar, ripe apples and leather, flavours of ripe apples on the border of being overipe and some woodiness, long appley sour aftertaste which is quite pleasant.  A solid well made cider, though not very complex.

UPDATED: MAY 14, 2011 At a tasting, 2008 vintage, pours clear bubbly yellow with a greenish shiny taints with almost no head, aroma of olives, sour apples, barnyard, sulfur, honey, apple skin and wood, flavor is sweetish with nice carbonation , green apples, rotten apples and nice acidity, full bodied. @ a tasting, pours yellow shiny, sticky and slightly hazy with a small white head, begins with aromas of brett, then comes nice acidity of green apples, wood and cherry liquor, flavor is rather sweet, with dominant apple juice and vinous flavors, barnyard and fermentation tones can be sensed, robust body. Fine cider

Corked bottleRécolte 2006Passage en fût 2007 (for 6 months)Golden color, the finest perlage; small crown of foam on the upper sides of the glass. Delicate apple juice aroma, hint of hazelnuts. The flavor is half-sweet, moderate apple flavor; there is an exogenous note, but I cant tell if its the Calvados; it misses some depth and the woody astringency that I like in French ciders. Elegant but not impressive.Earlier Rating: 2/5/2007 Total Score: 3.8Corked bottle, Recolte 2004, 2+ years oldHazy golden color; nice thin perlage. Strong aroma, of Golden apple peel, oxydized. Good body structure, with some sweetness in the front, juice of mature yellow apples, a hint of honey. The final gets some complexity by being lightly astringent; the apple flavor lasts for long. Very good.

Clean as a whistle, and some obvious fruit sweetness, but you will struggle to find a better made cider. Minerals, cut stone and salt combine very well in the palate against the apple friuts. Dangerously quaffable despite its 7.5%.

2008.  Effervescent like nothing else.  The flute is full of bubbles which create a constant unstable tidepool on the surface.  Bright yellow.  Golden delicious and band aid aroma.  Very strongly sweet, scrubbed a bit by the carbonation and controlled in its oaky finish.

2003 bottle sample at Muckfest 2009 Day 1. Cloudy/chunky orange pour with no carbonation.  Funky aroma of vinegar and apples.  Funky and yeasty aroma balanced by sweet apple and a sour vinegar finish.

2005 Version Very Generously Supplied by vyvvy
Aroma.  Shit.  I dont even want to drink this.  I want to smell it all night.  Maybe stick my wiener in it for a bit.
Honey, love, possibly some KY Warming Jelly.
Taste, umm, i am scared.  Taste is very sweet, surprisingly sweet.  Not quite complex at the colder temperature currently served, but well refrain. 
Taste is sweet honeyed apple, carbonated, and just plain yummy.
Not overly complex, but pure, clean, incredible. 
Perhaps a bit too sweet considering the lack of depth.
As you swirl it in your mouth, the spiciness, the fullness really comes out.  
Yummy.  Aroma kills the taste.

Bottle thanks to sloth. Apples from 2007, matured in 2008, marked [7] 08422, at 6.9% ABV.  Pours with a frothy white head that fades to a ring over a hazed, bubbly gold body. Aroma of barnyard, manure, brett, sourness, green tart apples, calvados and straw. Taste is sweet, with a light funk, really bright and vibrant apple flavor, apple brandy (calvados), and light spices. Lively effervescence, dry mouthfeel, highly drinkable. Truly spectacular!

Botella con la familia nostra. Récolte 2006, passage en fut 2007.  L 0808. Unclear deep nice golden colour. Very pleasant apple, wood, calvados bit sweet aroma. Good mouthfeel. The flavour has a some sweetness with woody calvados and tasty queezed apples and a pleasant alcohopl touch. Apple woody soft alco calvados finish, Great cider indeed!
Bottle. Sweet and a biy dry wooden apple aroma and some yeast. Golden yellow colour with diminutive white head. Dry and sweet apple flavour. Aftertaste dry. Rich carbonation.

Bottle 75 cl. Courtesy of yespr. Calvados barrel. Pours almost clear yellow with a rough and bubbly white head. Fresh and complex aroma of apples and a little wood. Full-bodied with fairly sweet apple notes, a little sulphur and again a touch of wood. some alcohol in the finish. 210309Earlier Rating: 12/17/2006 Total Score: 3.4(Bottle 75 cl) Pours a hazy golden with a somewhat rough, white head. Very tart apple aroma with a whiff of wood. Light body with very soft and sweet apple accents. Odd how the aroma is so tart while the flavours are all smooth, soft and sweet. Quite a complex and pleasant country cider. 151206

Bottle, 7.5%. Weak apple aroma. Hazy yellow colour. Frothy white head. The flavour is nicely sweet with lots of good apple notes. A little alcohol note in the finish balances off the sweetness and fruitiness well.

Bottled, 7,5%. A hazy light yellow cider with a thin white head. The aroma is sweet and acidic with strong notes of apples and some calvados. The flavor is sweet with a nice edge of acidity and strong notes of apples and medium notes of calvados and light notes of over ripe apples, leading to a tart finish.Earlier Rating: 12/16/2006 Total Score: 3.6An unclear orange cider with a bubbly and quite fast reciding head - a long lasting head for a cider. The aroma is sweet with a lovely combination of apples and desert wine as well as an acidity from the apples. The flavor s very sweet with lovely apple notes, but also with an acidity, but also with fruity notes - I pick up peaches, as well as notes of desert wine. The mouthfeel is very rounded, except in the end where a slight alcohol bite show its teeth.

75 cL bottle, 7.5%. Pours slight cloudy yellow with a fizzy white head. Dry wooden apple aroma with a mild sulphorish note. Sweet fruity with a nice wooden accent to a light sulphorish note from back of the nose. Sparkling carbonation mouthfeel. Sweet and subdued sulphorish finish with a nice mellow wooden note.
Dark in color with what I guess is yeast.  Neither dry nor sweet.  Some chocolate and spice.  Low carbonation.  I dont drink much hard cider so I can compare, but this was worth repeating.

330 ml bottle. Very dark brown, almost black. Looks clear, but it is
  hard to tell. Dry papery roasted aroma with a distinct yeasty
  note. Soft texture with a rounded mouthfeel. Fairly low carbonation
  level. Roasted flavours, but they are quite mellow. The yeast can
  also be found in the flavour. Rounded flavours with a hint of
  chocolate and coffee. Nice, but the yeastiness is bad.

750ml bottle poured into a wine glass.  I shared this bottle with Brooke.  This is easily the best cider I have ever had.  That being said, my experience with cider is quite limited.  I thought the body was a great balance between dry and sweet.  The taste was delicate and balanced.  I would be more than willing to have another bottle of this or to keep some handy in the cellar for nice dinners.
Hands down the best cidre I have ever had. Gorgeous gold coloration and a sweet apple (obviously) taste. Bit of spice etc...but real real good.

Recolette 2006, passage en fut 2007, enjoyed December 2008. The color is warm golden and the head is small. The aroma has notes of sweet apples and is very full and alluring. The flavour has sweetness and notes of sweet apples with a light, dry bitterness, hints of wood, honey and the finish is slightly spicy. It is incredibly smooth and pleasant, and I find it hard to describe it  but nice it is, that is for sure...

Biggish offwhite coarseish head does not last. Hazy pale amber body. Hazy pale amber body with carbonation. Sugary wooden metallic apple aroma with earthy notes. Dry-sweet wooden alcoholic apple taste with earthy metallic notes. Intensely dry aftertaste of winter apple. Nice, but a bit intense, perhaps. (0.75l bottle, wine monopoly, Oslo.)

22oz bottle at the SATRG. Hazy gold with floating bits of apple skin. Big apple nose, real fresh apples. A light bit of funk and a some brown sugar and cinnamon. Very sweet with a lively but not prickly carbonation. Calvados lends a heavy woody vanilla note at the backend. One of the best ciders I’ve had.

750ml bottle shared by iowaherkeye. Poured a slightly hazy golden color. Smelled of apple, subdued cinnamon, and a hint of funky cheese. Sweet on the tongue and appropriately effervescent. I tasted apple, obviously, but didn’t get much in the way of calvados/barrel other than the faintest hint of vanilla. Nice cider.

awesome looking bottle,  thanks iowaherkeye.  Golden with a thin white head.  Aroma is oak and funk.  Flavor isn’t nearly as funky,  and the oak goes away.  Lots of apple and pear in the flavor,  just a touch of honey as well.  Snappy carbonation on this one in the finish.

25 oz bottle, via TheCheeseMan.  Pours a clear dark gold body with a minimal to no head.  Great aroma of sweet and tart crisp apples, pear, woodiness, and honey.  Great sweet fresh tasting apples with the calvados emerging nicely on the finish giving it a depth to the flavor unlike most Ciders that I’ve had.  Honey, light floral notes, a little bit of spiciness and wood.  Mouthfeel is medium bodied with nice soft carbonation.  Excellent.

Pours a cloudy dishwater sort of color with little head.  Aroma is a little sweet with some good cellared apple smell in there.

Flavor is very sweet with a bit of a strange aftertaste.  Like a way to overripe red delicious or something.  Maybe this one is to sweet for me, but overall not very tasty for a high end cider.

Bottle  75 cl. A bright clear yellow and bubblish appearance. The nose is fresh and fruity (apples) . Perfect on a base of fois gras de Gascogne. The flavour is like smooth dessert-wines like a good suternes and you sense the oak. The palate is sparkling and rich carbonated.

Bottle shared by a generous local.  Poured a clear golden color with a fizzy white head that faded to a ring.  Aroma of green apples and a nice brandy-like presence.  Tart apple with a nice oak presence and a light brandy booziness make up the flavor.  Moderate to high carbonation.  Pretty nice.

Bottle from New Beer - 04 harvest/05 maturation.  Light golden color with a fizzy head.  Nice funky-sour apple aroma that is reminiscent of a good gueuze.  Flavor has a nice subtly sour apple taste with some bretty-like funkiness.  Good use of wood here as well - really nice mouthfeel as well.  A nice mix of slightly sweet and tart apples.  A really nice cider.

750ml, 2007.  Cloudy straw colored pout with a soapy head that leaves immediately.  Great funky, yeasty, appley smell - the oak and calvados are in there too, and it works really well (even though Im not a huge fan of calvados in general).   Super refreshing - pithy sourness with enough sweetness to balance.  Musty and spicy qualities in the finish.  Really smooth and its amazing how much clean apple flavor there is in the finish.  This would be the perfect cider to go with a holiday meal or to break up a tasting of big barley wines or imperial stouts.  Really enjoyable.

2006 corked bottle, the label said 7.5 % ABVSlightly unclear greenish yellow colour. Refreshing apple aroma with notes of gunpowder. Sweet and sourish, earthy taste of winter apples. Some calvados and oak flavour in the background. Very elegant and really tasty.

2004 apples, bottled in 2005, and consumed December 2007.  The pour is a mostly clear, very lightly hazy, light golden honey color.  A very fine edge of bubbly foam defines itself atop the flute.  Light cascades of carbonation bubbles stream their way to the surface as if this were a fine champagne.  Barely noticeable, tiny particles of sediment float amongst the bubbles.  The aroma is of well aged apples, calavados musk, funky wood and earthy notes.  A touch of dry cinnamon and nutmeg add a spicy depth.  The flavor is dry and crisp, as it should be, with tart green and sweet red apples showing strong.  Musty wood is a nice, complimentary flavor.  The calvados is up front, obvious, and pleasing.  Semi-dry and medium bodied, this cider sports a moderately lively mouthfeel.  This is a very pleasing concoction.  Perfect for a Fall day.

2003 bottle courtesy of willblake.  Jon passed this on to me about 3 years ago and have been sitting on it ever since.  No head and no carbonation.  Funky sour apple aroma.  Lots of leather and vinegar.  Did not expect it to be so "infected".  But maybe it is supposed to be that way.  Color is a cloudy golden orange.  Wow super smooth and succulent.  Just a hint of sourness in the flavor that absolutely makes the mouth salivate.  Crap I am almost drooling.  Light apple flavor with maybe a hint of the white grapes.  Tangy spices late swallow with some lingering tartness and a light alcohol presence.  Very easy drinking
Dry puckering finish that leavs you begging for more.  Not sure if it was supposed to taste like this but it has matured into some pretty damn good stuff.

Bottle. Aroma of musty apples and a hint of barnyard funk. Lots of tart, sour and dry wood notes. Pours cloudy orange with no head. Looks still. Excellent balance on the palate of tart and sweet apples with a nice dry woody finish. Medium bodied. Despite the appearance of the pour, good carbonation. Finishes with a lasting tart dryness.

Shared by Styles.  Hazy golden brown appearance with a medium to thin head.  The aroma is very awesome--plenty of apples, some grapes, and a hint of oak.  The flavor follows, but the apples are more sour than expected.  Really nice brew.

Courtesy of Styles
Bottle:  The aroma is a combination of sweet and faintly tart apples with a hint of whiskey and faint spices.  It pours a hazy gold with some large sediment and a small fizzy white head.    The flavor starts much like the aroma with sweet and faint tart apples.  It finishes with a hint of spiciness and alcohol with an increased tartness.
2004 Bottle: Pours a hazy gold with a white head. Aroma, apples, fruits, and some cinnamon. Flavor, light apple notes, cinnamon, sugary. This was pretty good.

UPDATED: OCT 2, 2007 750ml bottle, 2005 release.  Rich, sumptuous apple aroma, also features hints of honeyish sweetness, sulfur, brett (or something similar) barnyard and fruity tartness.  Cloudy golden amber color, mostly lasting thin head, unfiltered.  Velvety apple flavor, sweet and rich, yet light, very flavorful.  Smooth mouthfeel, effervescence is gentle.  Finishes strong and satisfying.  Pretty good stuff, this is about the pinnacle of craft ciders by far in my limited experience.  Just fits the profile I had in my head of what good cider could be.

vintage 2004.  Huge apple aroma, red apples, with hints of sour apple skins.  Pours amber with no visible sign of carbonation.  Taste is all apples, enough carbonation to tickle the tongue.  Good apple flavor, red apples again with hints of apple skins and some hints of oaky vanilla flavors.  Very enjoyable to drink.

The 5th and last cider in our flight at Indras Mead, Cider and Sake Tasting 8/31/07. 2004 harvest aged in Calvados until 2005. Pours a cloudy gold with a few floaties and a thin white head that clings to the edges of the glass. Light brett-like funkiness on the nose with nice sweet apples and a hint of woodiness. Medium-bodied and slick, it finishes quite tart and dry. The flavor is a beautiful, round, vinous apple with calvados/woody notes. This was hands-down the best cider of the evening, and IMHO it was the best locally-available beverage of the evening.

Bottle bought at Systembolaget, Göteborg, Sweden. Abv 7.5 % according to the label. Cloudy orange golden with a small and short head.  Creamy apple aroma with some woody notes and a pungent alcohol bite. Light to medium bodied with a lively sparkling mouthfeel. Quite dry with a gentle bitterness.

Murky yellow golden.  Tart, musty, tannic, and oak aromas.  There was some disscussion of brett in this.  I can certainly pick up the calvados.  Sweet apple flavors.  Well rounded palate with a dry finish.  This is a very nice drink.

Fifth cider of the night at the Indra - Cider, Sake and Mead tasting 8/31/07.  Pour is very bubbly, hazy orange yellow.  Aroma of funk, barnyard and almost bret wildness.  Taste is initially quite sour, middle is sweet full body, than mellows out to a nice crisp sourness in the finish.  Most certainly the best of the ciders we sampled.

went in with a closed mind, and came out open minded towards ciders.  Poured a sparkling yellowy color aroma was light graps and apples.  Flavor was apples and grapes sour and sweet.  Very very enjoyable.

2004 apple harvest, matured until at least 05, aged in Calvados. Wonderful sparkling golden pour, head fizzled quickly, though. The aroma was beautiful, musty, cellar-like apples and light grapes, sour-ness even detectable. The flavor was super soft, lightly sweet finish to almost perfectly balance out the light tartness of the apples, some grapes, musty cellar notes throughout, very nice. A very pleasing and gentle cider, not up to the shock and awe of La Face Cache ice cider, yet subtle, gentle, and complex enough to please me.

Sampled during Cellars Wine & Spirits Friday evening beer tasting. A 2005 vintage, pours a semi-clear pale golden brew with a fizzy white head that quickly dissolves to a fine film and ring. Aroma of sour apples, yeast and a touch of corlaner. Taste is medium bodied, spritzy, with flavors of sour apples, some light white bread, yeast and some musty wood. Finish is a bit gritty, some sour apples and yeast in the aftertaste. A nice barrel aged cider.
Bottle from a Cellars tasting.  Calvados nose with a sweet tinge.  Oak taste with a calvados flavor and a rough cider finish to it.

Bottle of the 2004.  Rich yet ephemeral flavor of apple pastry, the only fault I could find in the taste is that I wanted more of it.  Finish has the tiniest hint of brandy barrel.  This is just delicious.

Pours orange with lots of soda-esque carbonation and a large short lasting white head.  The aroma has ripe red apples, apple mash, some spice and yeasty qualities.  The flavor starts with the apples, some odd yet nice alcohol haste, oak, peppery spice and white Im assuming is the calvados casks.  The finish has more of what is probably the calvados, yeastiness and tangy spice.  Very nice and interesting, but at the price I probably wont have it too often.

Slightly hazy pale with medium sized white head, nice retention for a cider. The aroma is slightly tart, apples, funk and just a touch of plastic. The flavor is brightly acidic, tart apples, light sugars and light cheese. Medium/light body with a sparkling mouthfeel. Very nice indeed.

Hmm, I dont find this one quite as good as the other I tried. Aroma was mainly apples, a hint of funk, musty, and a touch of wood. The flavor was similar, with an interesting combination of appley sweetness and a medium tannic tartness. The finished seemed to be papery, woody and perhaps stale. Is this oxidation from the aging? Cloudy yellow.
bottle. murky yellow color. sour aroma. apples in taste. very sweet and carpy. some dry aftertaste of pear.

Cloudy golden colour with a thin white head. Light tart apple fruity aroma with notes of wood and a vague alcohol sweetness. Sweet and very balanced flavor with notes of wood and a light acidic fruityness.

Very good lambic-like aroma.  Lots of yeast with a barnyard character.  Very bright and cloudy yellow.  I thought the alcohol was a little higher.  Flavor has apple with a good balance between sweet and sugar.

Nice tart apple aroma with a hint of earthiness as well.  Great balanced flavor that definately gives off some of the Calvados flavor.  Nice sweet upfront with a great caramel and minerality on the finish.  Very nice cider.
user_location: Farewell Minny; Hello Puyallup, Washington, USA

text:
Pours a clear golden color, and even though the cider is not carbonated, there is a quarter inch of white foam that lasts a minute or two, the dies back to a small clump of bubbles and a ring. A few brown yeast flecks swim around for a while, then settle to the bottom of the glass. Apple, honey, oak, and alcohol in the aroma.

More of the same in the flavor - dark sweet honey, oak, and sweet apple. Also some pear and a trace of vanilla. Medium body, smooth mouthfeel. Only a hint of alcohol in the flavor, but a nice mellow alcohol warmth is noticeable. It feels like more than the 6% abv listed on the bottle
Bottle. Cloudy colour with a weak head. Sour and acid aroma with notes of apples. Sweet, tasty flavour with notes of apples. Very refreshing and nice, also very easy to drink.

Bottle.
Hazy yellow coloured with a white head.
Aroma of apples and wood.
Flavour of apples and wood.

(750 ml bottle from Swedish Systembolaget) LAbeled 5.5%. Shady orange color, pretty much no head. Very sour initial scent, some stables and horses, cheeze, might almost have guessed it for a lambiv or a gueuze. Still some sweet apples in the back. Sweet almost thick mouthfeel. Some apples during the first taste, very clear sweet apple aftertaste. A little bit sour. No bitterness.

UPDATED: DEC 14, 2006 [Bottle from Beermouth tasted with the hop-bros at Jess cosy inn.]

Beer/Cider no. 150!! My first real cider indeed. A wonderful, but also challenging taste of fruit mixed with mould notes. There is something rotten in this cider, which is the quality. Fresh and bitter, sparkling, very old sweet apples. A surely taste of the old calvados oakcasks. Must try it again.
Bottle from beermouth. O´boy i do like this one, it is off the scale. Spice Appel A bit fizzy what can i say. ;O)
UPDATED: NOV 22, 2006 Yellow with orange edge and a tiny head. Fresh apples, lemon, spice and grass. Fresh, bitter but still with a tiny sweetness. Yummi!

750 mL corked/caged bottle labeled 2004, with slight discoloration on the cork.  not to be deterred, i poured into several glasses to share.  sweet and appley, sweeter than i expected and less carbonated than i expected - the carbonation seemed to have entirely dissipated after the pour.  brandy liqueur elements are present - predominantly sweet.  if it were drier, this would be excellent.

750mL, 2004 vintage.  Cloudy, golden, white-grapefruit appearance; slight bubble retention around the edges.  Tart cider, olives in the nose; slightly medicinal.  Crisp apple tartness, a bit of pepper, matched by a whiskey-like (apple brandy, evidently) character; Ali thinks it tastes like green olives, which isnt so far off.  Medium finish suggests a stale apple quality; whisky, sour-mash edge.  Strange, medicinal cider.

Bottle from Super Saver.  Hazy dark straw pour with 1-finger off-white head and brown floaties.  Strong apple aroma, with some cinnamon, slight oaky notes, and some caro syrup.  Nice complex palate, with apple flavor coupled with a solid density and complexity.  Stays on the sweet side, with a complex palate.

Pours a lovely hazy wheat color, kind of like a good hefe, with moderate champagne-like carbonation and a thin head that quickly disappears.  Faint aroma of apples (do I have it too cold).  Flavor is of slightly sweet apples with notes picked up from the oak casks.  Very nice.

2004 Vintage: Pours perfect yellow gold w/ a short lived, shallow spritzy froth. Strong aromas of cedar cigar box w/ wild apples and seltzer. Medium nectar w/ ample residual effers. Champagne size bubbles. Flavors are crisp and mellow,  tart-sweet  w/ an oaky character. I taste wild apples, green peaches, and kiwi fruit. Finishes long and fruity w/ slight bittering. Overall: very complex, not too sweet and very well balanced. I highly recommend this to any connoisseur and cider drinker.

Poured a semi-hazy effervescent golden with a small fizzy white head that dissipated completely.  Beautiful nose of sweet and sour apple, cinnamon, sweet vanilla, touch of maple syrup.  Taste is a good balance of sweet and tart, with the apple flavor coming through first, though tastes a bit like caramelized apples.  This is then joined by a smokey, brandyish flavor that actually marriages with the apple flavor quite nicely.  This does not have the heavy, syrupy flavor or body of an apple-wine, but is instead a great fireside cider with a pronounced but refined flavor.  Delicious.

Thanks to Jeffn7 (Secret Santa) for this.

Brilliantly clear, rich golden colored still cider.
Lightly spicy, fresh apple aroma.
Simple yet very well done, just lots of fresh apple flavor. 
Light yet coating, no feel for any alcohol here. Very easy drinking, refreshing sipper.
2004:  Pour is hazed deep golden coclor...smell is yeast, apples, and alcohol...seet still viscous apple flavor...nice...

04 bottle, shared at Dickinsonbeers pre-TAP gathering.  opened this one when everyone was "saturated" or passed out.  only the strong survive!  cloudy golden yellow color.  aroma is fresh-from the farmers market granny smith apples.  a little yeast too.  flavor is fresh apples with their skins (but no seeds or core).  and a dryness like a white wine.  incredible cider, I went and bought another bottle of it the next day.
Amber haze with no head or lace. Warm apple pie aroma with some notes of cinnamon. Applesauce and brown sugar. A touch earthy and hot. Kind of flat. A touch thick.

750 mL bottle, corked & caged (2004 version, sampled April 2006): cloudy orange gold, minimal off white head.  Mushy, red delicious apple juice aroma, with hints of dirt, moss and yeasty funk.  Nice tartness on the tongue, very fresh green apple flavour coupled with mild fruity malts and a bit of honey.  Very enjoyable.

Slightly hazy golden body with a fluffy, quickly-diminishing white head.  A wonder sweet, slightly spicy nose of fresh, crisp apples, vanilla, cinnamon, light oak, very subtle funkiness and some residual sweetness.  The body is pretty light and crisp with solid carbonation that really sparks the tongue.  This is a treat to drink, the crisp apples, vanilla and oak are so refreshing and enjoyable, while the cider is neither too sweet nor too heavy.  The finish is crisp, slightly tart, and refreshing.  Lip-smackingly good.  Thanks again Justin; this was a treat!

2004 Vintage.  Bright gold color with a medium white head.  Dry apple aroma with a bit of "fresh rain on the field".  The taste is decidedly Calvados.  Obviously the apple is still there, but is much more alcoholic.  Plenty of oak from the barrel and a little vanilla towards the end.  Its still tasty, but this is like some whisky barrel aged stouts in that it is almost more like the liquor that was in the barrel the first time around than the beer or cider that it supposedly is.

2004 bottle.  Glowing straw gold, no head.  Nose has fresh apple, oak, strawberries, earthy wood.  Flavor shows apple, mustiness, brown sugar, wood, caramel.  Vanilla and orange notes in the musty finish.  I like the regular more.

2004 Vintage. Brownish gold. Fresh apple aroma, as might be expected, plus some hints of sour dough. Flavors are a comples mix of apple, stone, lemon amd chardonnay, plus a hint of vanilla. Really tasty.

Cloudy peach-colored body with no head to speak of.  Gentle apple and peach aroma as well with a nice tartness.  The flavor is quite sweet and has a very natural apple quality to it:  somewhat sour, honey-sweet, yeasty and perfectly tart.  One of the best and well-balanced ciders that Ive had.

Cloudy straw/grain color, with nearly zero carbonation, but some large, clinging bubbles none-the-less - very sweet aroma or honey and overripe apples, some earthy, barnyardy must - starts dry and crisp, but just a bit of tartness - very sweet through the middle, with the honey and overripe apples from the aroma coming through - oak and vanilla come in near the finish - doesnt finish as dry as some ciders, but a tannic (as others have noted), chardonay-like quality does come in to balance the sweetness - a very nice cider.

This seemed like a cider crossed with a lambic or funky saison.  Started off with some nice crisp sweet apple flavors and a lot of carbonation.  Dry and woody at the finish with hints of liquer.  After awhile, i definitely got "wild" - almost barnyard stuff here.  A little bit of sourness.  Fairly complex for a cider.

2004 bottle.  Cloudy deep golden cider, almost still appearance.  Lovely sweet aroma, fresh apple, honey, a touch of funkiness.  Spicey nose, vanilla and a bit of dustiness.  Flavour is quite sweet, almost bready mouthfeel, apple and oak flavour.  The Calvados really comes through on the finish.  Almost brandyish sweetness through the middle.  Very nice tasty cider.

04 Bottle, thanks Chuck. Pours a murky golden color, no head. Aroma is musty apples, cobwebs, hay. Flavor starts syrupy and sweet, apples of all sorts. Sweet malt liquory body finishes slightly bitter/sour apples.

2004 Bottle... Hazy, deep golden cider. The acidic aroma is all apple and wood with healthy doses of booze and leather. Woodsy, caramelly flavor with a quick flemish quality up front and a mild, slightly astringent, tannin bite on the backside. Medium-bodied and watery with lively carbonation. Finishes dry and tannic.

The aroma is pear, yellow apples, and light peaches.  The flavor is peaches and apples that have some fresh vanilla and sweet brandy.  The appearance is a hazy golden straw color with a non-existent head.  Looks good for a cider.  The palate is a tart and sweet with lingering appley goodness.  Nice mouthfeel.

vintage 2004
orangish color tiny whisps of white head.  smells a touch wine like has hints of alcohol in it.  A lot of tart apples a touch floral and some vanilla maybe even a touch of brandy in it.  Good mouth feel well coated and smooth.  The flavor is definatelly full of sweet sugars and apples some vanilla and a tiny twinge of sweet brandy some wood notes come out now and again inconsistnantly.  Pretty good cidar.
Sediment throughout and no head.  Hazy brownish color. Oak dry flat palate not very sweet taste.  Tart apple and has some wine like tannic qualities like they through in the stems of the apples.

2004. Golden pear color and slightly hazy with very fine misty bubbles that could easily be overlooked. Aroma of apple jelly with flowery notes, some spice, distinct oak, and a hint of vanilla. Flavor is of ripe apples and peaches with subtle biting spiciness and brandy notes. Medium sweet with even tartness some tannic bitterness and a long, woody finish. Nice texture. Fine carbonation keeps it lively. Part of me wants this to be drier but I wouldnt want to sacrifice the nice body. Great depth. Blows away any cider that Ive had.

UPDATED: AUG 4, 2005 2003 bottle, thanks to my girlfriend who brought it back from France!  At first, poured a bubbly, clear, very light gold, with essentially no head.  Looked champagne-like.  Towards the bottom of the bottle, pours became cloudy, opaque, and with floaties.  Aroma is sweet apples, lightly musty, stale, moldy, band-aid -- lots of "farm" aromas.  Light vinegar.  Later pours were woody, yeasty.  Very complex.  Taste is, of course, sweet apples, lightly sour but with a good amount of astringency (granny smith).  Stale, oxidized, woody.  The aroma became yeasty as the taste did and the appearance clouded.  Great mouthfeel from the dryness & astringency.  Tartness does not quench your thirst -- it leaves you wanting to drink more -- but the sweetness almost negates this effect.  I am a big fan of French-style cidres.  This one was delicious and beautiful.

Translucent orange-amber body, no real head or carbonation.  Softened, oxidizied macintosh apple  aroma with fresh tart green apple skin and sweet mushroom eath.  The aroma also has a dry oaky air about it, this comes along with the mushy apple sweetness.  Semi-dry mouthfeel but with a tannic sweetness.  The flavor features green apple tartness, that same mushy macintosh sweetness, and concentrated apple juice (yes, the canned stuff).  The barrel-aging might be present in the light bitterness that exists over the whole flavor.  This stuff needs more carbonation, it feels flat and sweet on the tongue.  This could be a great spritzy drink.

2003 Bottle:  Very cool cage deal on top of the cork.  Pours a perfect cloudy tan.  Bustling carbonation.  Musty ripened apple nose, plum and wine, faintly spiced.  Very nice mouthfeel, dusty, leather, obvious apples, faint horseblanket, bandaid, citrus, finishing with a white peppery calvados burn.  Quite nice, please let this warm.  This wasnt what I had anticipated, but quite good nonetheless.  A tad expensive, this is still a cider that needs to be tasted.  These guys know how to do their ciders.
Cloudy tan colour.  Minimal visible carbonation.  Fruity, tannic, alcoholic aroma.  Flavour is sweet, with an appley, leathery character.  Finishes soft and smooth, which is a bit of a letdown.

2004 Bottle: Corked: Hazy gold color, no head, no lacing and light carbonation. Nose of musty apples and prunes. The flavor is dusty and sweet with apples and calvados. Finishes with some tobacco flavors. Good but the lack of carbonation doesnt bode well with with this cider.

UPDATED: DEC 30, 2007 Pours a hazy yellow and smells of leather and apples.  As the cider warms, the dominant smell is funky with apples, some wood and mellow alcohol present.  Taste is a nice blend of dry, tarte and sour apples, oak, some farmhouse funkiness and a great dry apple/oak finish.  One of the more rustic ciders Ive had.  The calvados hints pop through on the finish, giving this cider a distinctively aperitif like finish.

Lightly hazy goldend orange...Apple suace nose with light spice and pureness. Flat with a sweetness that is balanced by a nice acitdity. Appley, with pear and some mineral notes with a nice tartness to round it out. Nice but not as amazing as I was hoping for.
Clear golden color.  The aroma is quite gueze like with some vinegar.  Flavor of apples, but very tart and complex.  A beer to be savored.

Thanks to DAAS for sharing this. Murky orange/yellowish color with no carbonation or head. Aroma is dried fruits , green apple and brett. Taste had a caramel apple quality to it right after a funky gueuze-like taste. Some oak was noticed as well.

1/5/05.  Poured out of 750 mL bottle, sampled at RateBeer OBriens Gathering courtesy of DrunkAsASkunk on RateBeer 1/5/05.  Yellow hazy body with a rocky white head and only patchy, fast lacing.  Beautiful bretty, perfumey funk aroma.  A pleasure just to sit and take in through the nose.  Somewhat plain, gentle pear and apple cidery sweetness with some faint, dusty funk and foggy, soft cheese-like flavors.  Great green olive finish with all the fixins of haunting olive skins, oil, and stemmy goodness, a really good dryness.  Extremely long-lasting finish with the olives, terrifically interesting for what it is.  I just wish the cider flavors before the finish were more compelling to take this to another level.  Really excellent, nonetheless.

This is actually the first cider I have rated and what a treat it was.  It pours with a yellow body with a thin fizzy head and little lacing.   The aroma is slightly sour and vinious with a little barnyard and a nice apple note.   The flavor is slightly sweet yet slightly sour and appley with a little green olive.  The finish is full of green olive.  Light bodied, smooth and dry.

This was the beer of choice I decided to bring to the Welcome Visitors gathering at Obriens last night. This was my first cider and I truly didnt know what to expect... well...ummm WOW! This cider poured a light yellow golden color with a small dissipating head. Aroma is total funky barnyardiness..predominantly apple, funky cheeses, yeastiness, lemon, wonderful sourness...one of the  most perfect aromas I could have hoped for. The flavor is all green apples with tingling carbonation glancing over the tongue with a hint of pears and breadiness. Wonderful long-lasting mouthfeel, medium bodied, tart and crisp finish...wonderfully crisp! The tart crispiness couldnt have been better...this was a masterpiece and a marvel of an aroma. I will gladly spend $17 on another bottle.
2003-- Poursa hazy golden hue with aromas of yeast, sour apples, honey and bubblegum.  Flavors of blue cheese, green olives, apples, and a hint of pear.

UPDATED: MAR 9, 2005 2003  A hazy blizzard induced yellowish-orange color lay almost completely uncovered but emitted a mind bending and phenomenal aroma alive with beautiful funk, barns, leather, sour grape, and cheese covered green apple...Soft delicate apple flavors with a nice funky fermented background with strange touches of caulk.  As I sat at the table with 10+ ratebeerians, I exclaimed loudy that this cider tastes like Caulk.  we laughed and rejoiced. It was a grand time.

Pours a hazy apple cider golden color, it is completely flat, so does not have a head of any sort.  The aroma is dominated by strongly of fresh cut, sweet apples, almost even a concentrated apple note (perhaps from the Calvados).  The taste is quite sweet, and tastes of unfermented apple juice, plus hints of oak in the finish.  There is only a hint of wild fermentation funk here, and I am quite disappointed.  I was expecting something much more wild and complex.  As it warms up it gains a hint of funkiness, and a bit of tartness in the finish.  If you like the New Glarus Fruit beers, then this is right up your alley, I prefer a bit more dryness and a bit more complexity.  This is tasty enough, it is just that the sweetness drowns out the other flavors.

2004 vintage.  Hazy golden body, nary a head.  Nice sweet apple aroma, not too distinguishable from apple juice but with an earthy funk to it.  Nice, full sweet apple flavor with a vinous character, rounded out by woody flavors imparted by cask aging.  Woody finish that dries up the remnant apple sugars.  Its strange how apple beers can approach this flavor so closely.  Very tasty and addictive...but at $10.99/bottle, this wont be a common sip.

2003 Bottle.  New years style.  Sourish apple aroma, but there are also hints of yeast in the nose as well.  Slight banana like nose.  Sort of a woodsy aroma.  Mildly hazy blonde color with lots of chunks floating.  Had a very fizzy and very quickly dissipating white head.  Start is mildly sweet, turning quite carbonated and tart in the middle.  Finishes with a woody taste and a slight bitterness.  Too fizzy for me.  A solid cider, but not in the league of Leo Boutin Pomelle.

2004 bottle. Slightly hazy golden color, no head really but that was expected. Wonderful apple and oaky aroma along with some pear. Sweet apple flavor, definitely along the line of some more lighter colored apples, again some pear. Fairly thin mouthfeel, slightly dry. Very, quite a pleasant drink.

Cloudy yellow/gold color. Aromas of musty oak and apples. Flavors of musty apples, oak, earth, and some honey. Almost no carbonation, and a thin body. Im no expert on cider, but this is interesting, if not great.

12.25.04  2003 version, Ive been saving this for Christmas so it better be good!  Pours pale yellow, glowing, with fizzy and dissipating head.  Lively eff streams from etching.  NOse is musty apple, lots of wet wood, candi sugar, funk, funk, funk, and tart-sour-sweet.  Strong apple flavor with more wood and vanilla and more wood and so much apple and honey and wood; crisp, bright.  So much wood it almost gets intrusive, but such a strong apple presence and some brandy notes on finish mellow and help balance the stuff.  Lingering sweet wood and more brandy.  Excellent.

Effervescent cider appearance. Tall beige head that settles, but just a never ending stream of bubbles form the bottom of the glass with a sharp crackling ear. Barnyard and oaken apples aromas. I do catch a bit of key lime as well in the nose. Actually fairly thick and slightly oily on the palate, which surprises me with all the bubbles cascading upward. Lots  of apple flavors as expected with light sweetness carried away by apple skin dryness and a lightly acidic finish.  This looks great in a standard pilsner glass I bet it would look even better in a flute.

2004 Vintage, aged 6 months in Calvados casks - 750 ml pours a rather still 24k gold with particulate suspension, no head, no lace.  The aroma is of apples, wood, clover, and perhaps some wilderness happiness.  Aroma is a real winner with this one.  The flavor is sweet, apples, a touch sour, perhaps some cask notes, a bit of wild yeast, and quite nice.  It is almost like a mixture between a Lambic and some very nice Cider.  The body is still and almost astringent as it cleans the palate.  It is amazing how something could be so sweet, yet so dry at the same time.  Overall, sublime.  Yeah baby, this is what rating is all about...
(750ml bottle, 2003 vintage)  Pours a yellowish body with a small head.  Aroma of sweet apple cider.  Flavor of sweet apples and pears, but not as tart as I expected.  Dry palate.  Enjoyable cider!

2002 Bottle.  This was a present to my buddy who was leaving for his new job in seattle.  The initial pour was yellow with some haze and some sediment.  No head.  HUGE aroma of sweet fruit.  Reading other ratings, I see lots of comments about the watermellon aroma.  That sounds right, if watermellon could be a little tart or sour.  Absolutly delicious with plenty of upfront sweetness and a bit of geuze sourness on the finish.  Very dry finish.  So I guess it starts off like watermellon and finishes like a pear.  Best cider I have ever had.

Vintage 2003.  When I caught the first whiff, I immediately reacted that it was "watermelon and urine", and later I got the dimensions that approached a more lambic-like quality, which is not uncommon in the realm of fine ciders.  It is this that puts it in a class much more like English cask ciders than American mass-produced bullshit ciders.  Small floaties, hazy yellow with a light foam.  The flavors have a big apple note (obviously) with a lot of complexity and a big sweetness carrying through the finish.  I found myself a bit critical of that sweetness because it takes away the zing of a good dry cider.  It was a bit disappointing at that level, especially after enjoying the aroma so much.  Thanks Bu11zeye!

interesting aroma that is sweet vinegar/urine/feces/watermelon, but somehow isnt unpleasant. light yellow with particles floating. taste envelopes the tongue and lingers. very, very dry apple and peartaste that is tasty and extremely powdery mouthfeel.

Bottle. Nose smells like a Geuze-sour, horse blanket/farmhouse. Sweet tastes with notes of body odor, warm watermelon, light smokiness. There is a good amount of sourness here-not too sour, but just right. Very enjoyable.
Bottled. Yellowish and sparkling. Delicious light well balanced cidre, nicely dry with a delicate apple taste running throughout. Loved it.

A huge thank you to myparents for getting this for me at Premier. 2003 bottle. This is to strongbow what Veuve Cliquot is to Spumante Bambino. Absolutely delcious, understated and elegant. Pours a hazy yellowy green colour and smells almost like a toned down geuze. with notes of sourness horse blanket and apple. The taste is awesome, a touch of sourness s it warms with apples, honey and a barnyard taste. Incredible.

Scrumptious funky, acidic, sweet fragrances reach straight for the inner nostrils and grab onto the Epicurean mind...The said pleasure-seeker immediately runs down for the proposed feast and is at once greeted by sweet apples dipped in caramel, but quickly notices the quasi-absence of aforementioned acidity...The buffet is decadent for the sweet tooth, but sadly lacks that purported tartness although strangely enough, a gum-drying effect is definitely noted...A bit of a let-down considering the immensely pleasurable aroma, but nonetheless a truly enjoyable beverage, full of roaming intricacies...

2003 vintage
Pour is a non-event, with a typical looking cider as the result.  Then comes the aroma...leather and band-aid predominate.  Apples dont appear when poured cold...once warmed the apple is mild in the aroma, and moderate in the flavor.  Still, the flavor is largely that of a medium-bodied red wine.  The palate is the most compelling element, as there is a real evolution that goes from dry and crisp, to round and sweet as it sits on your tongue.

Very cloudy orange blonde color, almost no head. Powerfull and acidic apples aroma and flavor. Dusty mouthfeel. Its my first cider, really, and even if Im not used to taste ciders I can tell this one is something special and amazing.

Assertive, sharp apple aroma with some liquor and woody notes. Opaque yellow-tan and quite still and syrupy. Sharpness promised in the aroma is somewhat lacking in the flavour. Not much acid or bite. Sweet, round, mildly spicy apple flavour with warming finish. Still and simple in the mouth. Body is syrup-like and thick. Bottle enjoyed with beerbuzzmontreal, MartinT, Rastacouere and a gang of bierophoux.

Extremely murky orange to pear color. Lots of tiny sediments. Huge fruity aroma, red apples oriented fruit salad, but also subdued notes of pear, mango, peach, grapes.. Very estery, absolutely hidden alcohol. Complex and impressive and just very different from any other cider Ive had obviously. On the tongue, the peach and pear flavors still accompany the apples, but theres a big wood-barrel counterpart which is perhaps a bit overwhelming. I absolutely love the christmas tree feeling it gave me (christmas flavors from the light barnyardy touch and) In this regard, I cant wait to try the regular Dupont cider. Weird mouthfeel evolution. At first, its rather thick, sticky, extremely sweet, sugar cane like, but it somehow gets a bit astringent toward the end. No carbonation, Im wondering if I would have enjoyed it more with some.

2003 dated, 750ml bottle
Pours hazy golden color, no head, light carbonation. Certainly it has apples in the flavor, but there were other elements/complexities that I couldnt quite identify but I enjoyed. This is a nice drinking experience.

750 mL bottle, snifter, 2003 vintage.  Just smelling this I realize I have no qualifications for doing this cider justice in my rating...amazing.  I get apples (tart and sweet), vinegar, horseblanket, fried eggs, cask wood among other things. Hazy straw-peach color with practically no head save for a little fizziness.   Moderately sweet, lightly acidic flavor becomes a moderately sweet, lightly acidic finish.  Most of the aroma notes come through into the flavor, but the apples are dominant.  The funk is really secondary to the apples which is probably for the best.  Medium body, velvety texture, lively (but non intrusive) carbonation, drying finish.  The bottom line is: I dont care what the fermentables are...this is a classy beverage.  You must try this...split a bottle with another person if necessary...what an experience!

This corked and caged bottled cider marked 2002 poured a small head of quickly diminishing clear colored large sized bubbles that diminished to nothing left behind only a slight lacing.  The body was uncarbonated hazy and yellow brown in color.  It had a mild horse blanket aroma with notes of mild apples and dough.  The mouth feel was smooth and dry with a slight apple tartness to it.  The mouth feel mellowed in the finish.  It had a soft vanilla apple yeast flavor.  This has to be the best cider I have had to date.  AT 53 degrees, the recommended temperature, the apple flavor starts to come out more.  It was not present when colder.  The flavor also becomes more leathery and more dry.  The aroma also mellowed even more as a bit of clove and cinnamon came out to play,

750ml 2002. Corked & caged. Poured a small clear head with fine-medium sized bubbles. Cloudy, carbonated and a straw yellow hue. Apple aroma. Sweet, sour, tart and apple flavor. Smooth and sour mouthfeel. Light bodied.

An excellent nightcap.  Pours cloudy brown-yellow, hint of a head, smells some funky leather and horsiness, fizz, acid, apples.  Mouthfeel smooth and thick.  Taste a light balance between funk and tart apples.  Ends on a sweet note.  Sourish aftertaste as you breathe in and air hits the back of your throat.  Number 400.  Very good stuff.

trappist glass: strange; i thought i would really like this. low carbonation probably due to travel... apple, barn, and leather. theres an oddly nice corky oak taste as well. id have to have another... the next day i coulda swore i urinated exactly what this is. it smelled like what i had drank, but it was more potent despite it having only a hint of piss. perhaps i'm mistaken. interesting piss this is.

UPDATED: SEP 11, 2004 2003 bottle: Ill preface this by saying that this is the first real cider Ive had.  Didnt know quite what to expect, but Im quite impressed.  Pours a mildly hazy goldenrod with a few lingering bubbles, but mostly still. Aroma is most reminiscent of a honey baked ham of all things.  Has some barnyard character and a touch of sour apples in the nose as well.  Starts lightly sweet turning slightly more tart toward the finish.  Has some cheesy gueuze character to it as well  as some nice oaky calvados presence.  Finishes semi-dry and sticky with a good lingering apple flavor.  A very enjoyable and complex beverage.

This was excellent. A cider with a giant head...retarded. Pours a deep opaque straw color. White lacy head. Nose is sour, while at the same time very smoky and burnt. Notes of mesquite. The calvados comes alive on the tongue. Ridiculous. Apple, smoked mesquite, sherry, oak. Delectible. Couldnt finish it. The calvados left me with an intense black olive flavour.
G-rat

Hazy golden color,small white head that faded fast as hell.Nice over ripe apple aroma with some other smells in there that i cant put my finger on.The flavor was very nice,Lots of nice apple flavor some hints of spice and again like in the aroma a few flavor nuances that i cant quite describe.This is by far one of the better ciders out there and im glad i finally picked one up after over looking them for lord who knows how long.Well worth the price if you can find it.

Pours a hazy light amber with a lot of fizzy carbonation that fades almost instantly. Aroma is of slightly tart apples, cinnamon, and a little dry champagne. Flavor is of apples, wood, a slight smoke, and a slight dry champange. A lot like a cider, a lambic, and champange mixed. Somewhat mild but still complex. It finishes dry but with a slight dusty coating on the tongue. I must admit I am a novice with craft cider so it is hard to rate it to others of its style.

Medium haze in this medium gold cider.  No head at all after about 10 seconds.  Aroma is of baked apples sans seasonings, touch of cheese, wood, honeysuckle, and bacon.  Flavor starts with some tart apple flavors, slowly descending into a complex woody character.  Beautiful touch exhibited with the use of the Calvados barrels.  Faint lambic like funk.  Great stuff, 2002 bottling.

750 ml bottle, 2002, shared with Psychprof.  Gorgeous bright pale yellow-gold, scintillating and sparkling...sweet apple-brandy aroma with just a touch of yeast; complex fruitiness in the flavor which was, for me, just a touch too sweet...finishes with soft apple-honey-vanilla-oakiness.  I actually liked the "regular" Dupont better; this seemed not as complex and a bit too thick, though its still a great cider.

vintage 2002: Lightly hazed lemon. Light brett in the aroma is softened by tangy calvados, apple must, iron, and old wood. Superbly soft mouthfeel. Still and gritty. Sweet apple, peppery brett interplay. Succulent calvados remnants thicken the body, stifle the brett, and impart more richness to the apples. Restrained, yet well-placed, acidity in the center balances the sweetness. Finishes grittier than it is dry, with a mixture of sweet apples and savory calvados. Yeast pour adds little else, with the exception of gritting up the body. Wonderfully complex and funky.
user_location: Blue Ridge Mountains, North Carolina, USA

text: Positively luminescent, glowing golden fires, cloudy. Aroma is sooooo farmy, a bit yeasted, very fresh and pressed green appley. Sweet and ??pickles?? Bizarre, a fair alcohol punch, delicious - quite sweet (I could never say "dry" about this). Coutesy of the great Muzzle.
user_location: Łódż, Warsaw, Poland; Michigan, Ohio, USA

text: UPDATED: MAR 29, 2005 2002. Cloudy, rich apple yeastiness mixed with lemon. Smells of linoleum, plastic and slightly of moss. Soapy light golden. Sweet and soft, nothing artificial whatsoever. Granny Smiths dulled by liquor. Funky horse blanket as well. Just a slight bit of melon added in finish from the Calvados aging. Lasting crips and dry finish.

UPDATED: JUL 10, 2015 2002 vintage... Poured a hazy gold color with no head or lacing.  Aroma of horseblanket, and tart green apples.  Sweet apple, calvado, mild alcohol taste, spicy (cinnamon) finish.  Slick mouthfeel, my favorite cider, even though ive only had 3, but this was better than the non wood aged Dupont.

2002 Vintage. Pale gold w/ a syrupy haze and no carbonation. Mildly pungent, musty aroma of horse blankets, oak, and, of course, sweet apple. Sugary, juicy, somewhat vinous feel. Lovely apple brandy flavour w/ just a hint of tartness & notes of horse blanket, musty leather, & oak. Long, sweet finish. Good stuff!

UPDATED: MAR 2, 2005 2003 bottle. Virtually no head. Body is hazy dark yellow, bottle conditioned. Aroma is moderately yeasty (horseblanket, barnyard), with notes of sour apple, lime, pear, celery, bandage. Flavor is moderately sweet, lightly acidic. Finish is lightly sweet, moderately acidic, lightly bitter. Medium body, watery texture, lively carbonation. Funky, complex, nicely balanced, another winner from Dupont. 8/3/8/4/16=3.9

2004 bottle. Virtually no head. Body is hazy dark yellow, bottle conditioned. Aroma is lightly yeasty (horseblanket, barnyard), with notes of apple, caramel, hints of cask wood and grass. Flavor is moderately sweet, lightly acidic. Finish is lightly sweet, lightly acidic, lightly bitter. Medium body, watery texture, soft carbonation. Surprisingly docile and uneventful.  Virtually still, not much acidity to balance the sweetness, and not quite as funky/interesting in the nose.  This may not bode well for the 2004 vintage of the [better] Brut. 7/3/6/2/13=3.1

UPDATED: MAR 21, 2004 I hope everyone likes the pretty pic I took of this rare Dupont Reserve Cider - it's truly a beautiful bottle.  Musty and woody with a band-aid quality in the taste.  Rather dry and complex and the calvados casks have certainly imparted an alcohol quality to the cider.  Looks like unfiltered apple juice (nice and cloudy).  The aroma is only moderate, but the acidity must be high as this is a really astringent, mouth puckering cider (but not tart, mind you).  A true pleasure for those who love dry, astringent, woody and rare ciders.  I certainly did!
